content_scrubbed:
I didn't see anyone else post it, but [other coverage](http://www. huffingtonpost. com/jesse-kornbluth/the-police-riot-at-berkel_b_1091208. html) indicates that several of the people beaten were respected professors.

 the first woman (in pink) that the police drag out of the crowd by her hair is Professor Celeste Langan, a beloved professor of British Romanticism and media studies in my department and director of the UC Townsend Center of the Humanities. As she places herself in front of students, the police approach her with batons. She repeatedly told the police not to beat her but arrest her instead. As you can see here, they respond by dragging her out by force and throw her to the ground.

They also beat an elderly poet laureate.

 When the police violence occurred again later that night, they broke the ribs of another English professor, poet Geoffrey O'Brien. When the police wouldn't stop beating him even after he too had fallen to the ground, a good friend and fellow graduate student, Ben Cullen, rushed in and demanded that they stop. The police, in turn, rained multiple blows on him, bruising his ribs as well. And just in case it[.] not clear yet that the violence was not only against [.]ome kids looking to make a fuss,' the police also thought it necessary jab 70-year-old former Poet Laureate and Pulitzer Prize winner Robert Hass several times in the stomach with a baton as well.
